org.tmotte.tmplz

Class TemplateManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.tmotte.tmplz.TemplateManager

  • public class TemplateManager
extends java.lang.Object
    This class is used to obtain templates (instances of Section) ready for processing. These instances are not to be thought of as "reuseable"; for example, if a web application uses templates to generate dynamic HTML, every time it responds to an HTTP request it should invoke TemplateManager.getTemplate() to obtain a new template instance.
    It is of course completely reasonable to cache & reuse the text output from a template (e.g. from Section.toString()) in a multithreaded manner, since it's just a String.

    • Constructor Summary

      Creates a TemplateManager for obtaining templates.

      • setTemplateInterceptor

      • getTextLoadMgr

        public TextLoadMgr getTextLoadMgr()
        Before using TemplateManager, its TextLoadMgr must be configured with at least one TextLoaderFactory instance.
        See Also:
        TextLoadMgr.register(org.tmotte.tmplz.load.TextLoaderFactory)

      • setObjectFormatter

        public void setObjectFormatter(ObjectFormatter obj)
        Sets the default ObjectFormatter for all templates produced by this TemplateManager. Whenever a Slot is filled in, the ObjectFormatter will be invoked with the new Slot value (and name) and allowed to format the object. Note that Section.setObjectFormatter() will override this setting.
        See Also:
        Section.setObjectFormatter(ObjectFormatter)

      • setTagDelimiters

        public void setTagDelimiters(java.lang.String startTag,
                    java.lang.String endTag)
        Changes the default tag delimiters from [$ and ] to startTag and endTag. Another alternative is to use the TagWith tag to set the start/end delimiters on a template-by-template basis.

      • setAutoTrim

        public void setAutoTrim(boolean autoTrim)
        Turns on/off auto-trim, which attempts to trim line breaks and extra spaces resulting from tags placed on lines by themselves (presumably for clarity). Defaults to true. Does not trim very aggressively; for that, use the Trim template tag.
        Parameters:
        autoTrim - If true, tags on lines by themselves are trimmed.

      • setDestructiveShowTags

        public void setDestructiveShowTags(boolean tf)

        This controls whether Show tag "destroys" the corresponding Section so that it cannot be shown again, by parent templates or Java code. When destruction is turned off (the default), there may be an excessive proliferation of leftover Section elements from included templates. Note that these extra Sections can be removed using the Remove tag, however.

        The default value of this property is false.

        Parameters:
        tf - If true, a Show tag "destroys" the Section; if false, it does not.

      • setCaches

        public void setCaches(java.util.Map templateCache,
             java.util.Map textLoadMgrCache)
        Allows one to customize the Maps used for caching data. By default, HashMaps are used everywhere.
        Parameters:
        templateCache - This will hold the actual template (Section) objects.
        textLoadMgrCache - This can also be set via getTextLoadMgr().setCache(), but is included here for completeness.

      • setCheckForChanges

        public void setCheckForChanges(boolean alwaysCheckForChanges)
        Normally TemplateManager will check the underlying template to see if it's changed when a template is requested via getTemplate(path). This is slightly inefficient if one knows that the templates will not change (e.g. in a production system). Invoking setCheckForChanges(false) will turn the check off.

      • getTemplate

        public Section getTemplate(java.lang.String path)
        The easiest way to get a template. Invokes getTemplate(new Path(path), alwaysCheckForChanges);
        See Also:
        setCheckForChanges(boolean)

      • getTemplate

        public Section getTemplate(Path path,
                  boolean checkForChanges)
        This gets a template ready for threadsafe content generation.
        Parameters:
        path - A string or URL indicating a source for the content. This will be logged to the Log class at the "FINEST" setting.
        checkForChanges - If true, the underlying source content provider will be asked to check the source content for changes to the template. If false and the parsed template already exists, the template will be assumed up to date. This is useful when a call has already been made to getLastModified(String) or getETag(String), both of which check for changes to the template, such that we don't need to check a second time when we already know the template has changed.
        Returns:
        A template ready for use.

      • getTemplate

        public Section getTemplate(java.lang.String path,
                  boolean checkForChanges)
        This just invokes getTemplate(new Path(path), checkForChanges);

      • getETag

        public long getETag(Path path)

        Obtains an "entity tag" for a template, which in HTTP parlance is a text code designating the current version of a resource. Uses a simple checksum of the template source (String.hashCode()+String.length(), combined additively for all included templates). The checksum is only recalculated when the template changes.

        This also checks the template for changes, in which case the template will be reloaded. Thus getTemplate() can be invoked afterwards with its checkForChanges parameter set to false (otherwise one would end up checking the source twice, once each for getETag() & getTemplate()).

      • getETag

        public long getETag(java.lang.String path)
        For convenience, this invokes getETag(new Path(path)).

      • getLastModified

        public long getLastModified(Path path)

        Obtains a timestamp for the most current version of a template. This is useful in caching scenarios where one simply wants to know if the template has changed. Note that for templates with Include tags, the timestamp returned will be newest timestamp found among the main template and all its included templates, recursively.

        This also checks the template for changes, in which case the template will be reloaded. Thus getTemplate() can be invoked afterwards with its checkForChanges parameter set to false (otherwise one would end up checking the source twice, once each for getLastModified() & getTemplate()).

        Note that this is not a good value for the HTTP last-modified header when using load-balanced web servers, because it uses System.currentTimeMillis(), which will be different on every server; also, the value will change after every reboot. It is better to use Entity Tags, i.e. getETag().

        Parameters:
        path - Represents the path to the template.
        Returns:
        The last time that the source for the template changed. For templates that have Include tags, it will be the most recent timestamp from all templates involved.
        See Also:
        getETag(String)

      • getLastModified

        public long getLastModified(java.lang.String path)
        For convenience, this invokes getLastModified(new Path(path)).

      • forceReload

        public void forceReload()
        This clears the cache of all templates.
